title: Saturday March 29th
content: Today was another busy day as a mama of three. Taking Elijah to football Elaina to gymnastics Christopher to jujutsu then grocery shopping picking up stuff for my mom and my grandmother and forgetting about a hair consultation that I had and had to turn around to go back to that consultation, then coming home for like 30 minutes to then take Elaina to a birthday party. Everything was good. I was just tired. My ex-husband called while I was at the birthday party and was making small talk. I told him he could call the boys at home and then he decides to thank me for being a good mom to our children. I’m a little confused about that it’s random.

title: Headache from something so petty
content:
I am annoyed to see that I am living with someone who is supposed to be the man of the house but is not doing what they should do. Anyway, today he's cleaning, and all I said to him was, 'Don't cut down the plant.' He starts acting out and saying to me that I am not the one cleaning it and I am not going to maintain it. I can't understand why it's always a fuss. That fuss gets me so heavy because, as a child growing up, every day there was a fight at my family home. But yet the person I am with tends to love a fuss while saying he doesn't, though he keeps starting it. 
So far I was able to walk away, but the day isn't over he's going to find something else to fuss about. But I will be praying he doesn't. My thing is, he never acknowledges anything good I do. Either he pretends to forget that I am the one who always goes outside and cleans up while still trying to clean inside, or he just doesn't care. I would have our kids outside picking up the leaves that I put in piles to dispose of. But now I am pregnant and unable to do much for myself, yet he forgets that I am always the one trying. He's starting to change me. Or is it that I am starting to see that he just doesn't care about me or my opinion? Because lately, I am still hurt by things he says to me. I am left with a headache in my thoughts, asking myself why he is still with me and always treating me badly why?

recommendations.recommendation: Imagining the worst-case scenarios, such as assuming there will be more conflicts throughout the day. - Practice 'Decatastrophizing' by identifying the worst-case scenario, best-case scenario, and most likely scenario to challenge and balance your thoughts.

Assuming you know what your partner is thinking, such as believing he doesn't care or is intentionally forgetting your efforts. - Use 'Evidence Charting' by writing down evidence for and against these assumptions to develop a more balanced view.

Taking your partner's behavior personally, assuming his actions are a reflection of his feelings toward you. - Practice 'Distancing' by acknowledging that his actions may be influenced by factors unrelated to you and apply a more objective perspective.

content: Today during a team meeting, I presented an idea I was really excited about. But my manager quickly shot it down and moved on without much discussion. I felt embarrassed, like everyone thought it was a dumb suggestion. For the rest of the day, I kept replaying it in my head and wondering if I’m even good at this job. I left work feeling small and discouraged

recommendations.recommendation: Viewing the situation in absolute terms, such as seeing yourself as a complete failure because of one event. - Challenge all-or-nothing thinking by writing down evidence that contradicts this belief. List your accomplishments and positive feedback from others to remind yourself that one meeting does not define your overall competence.

Assuming you know what others are thinking, such as believing everyone thought your idea was dumb. - Practice reality testing by asking yourself: 'What evidence do I have that everyone thought my idea was dumb?' and 'Is there a more balanced way to view the situation?'

Imagining the worst possible outcome, like questioning your competency at your job over a single event. - Use the 'Worst, Best, Most Likely' technique: Write down the worst-case scenario, the best-case scenario, and the most likely outcome. This can help you see the situation more realistically.

title: March 30-31st
content: I’m at the doctors an office in my first day of spring break so not starting in a high note. But last night my mind was racing so much I wanted to journal about it. I let my twins sleep in the room with me and for some reason I kept feeling like I don’t spend enough time with them as I was looking at them. I was wondering if they really know how much I love them. My mind was also racing throughout the night about the relationship I’m in. When we met last year January, I told him I didn’t want a relationship I was still separated from my husband but not divorced yet. He still pursued. We’ve been together ever since then. I feel like it’s been a back and forth battle in my mind ever since. Last night, particularly, I was feeling like this relationship is some how blocking my spiritual relationship. I feel less connected to spiritually. Mostly because we have sex and I grew up believing you are not supposed to have sex outside of marriage. I love him and think he is a wonderful man and great life partner  in many ways but not spiritually. Ironically my ex husband was overly spiritual and pushed his beliefs on me and I hated that. I would really love some peace and clarity. Not to mention good sleep at night.

recommendations.recommendation: The tendency to imagine and believe the worst possible outcome, such as worrying excessively about not spending enough time with the twins and doubting if they know they are loved. - Use the 'Decatastrophizing' technique: Write down the worst-case, best-case, and most realistic scenarios for your concerns about your children. This will help you see that the worst-case scenario is unlikely and provide a more balanced perspective.

Seeing situations in black and white terms, such as viewing the relationship as either entirely good or entirely bad based on spiritual alignment. - Practice 'Cognitive Restructuring': Identify and challenge these black-and-white thoughts by listing positives and negatives of the relationship. Acknowledge the nuance and complexity, which can reduce anxiety about needing everything to be perfect.

Using 'should' statements that reflect rigid rules, like believing one should not have sex outside of marriage, causing guilt and anxiety. - Try the 'Reframing' technique: Replace 'should' statements with more flexible language, such as 'I prefer' or 'I would like to.' This shift can ease the pressure and reduce anxiety associated with rigid beliefs.

title: Travel

recommendations.recommendation: Worrying about future events, such as travel, which disrupts sleep and increases anxiety. - Practice 'worry postponement' by scheduling a specific time earlier in the day to focus on and write down travel-related worries, freeing up mental space at night.

Belief that inadequate sleep will completely ruin the travel experience, increasing stress and anxiety. - Use cognitive restructuring to challenge these thoughts by listing past instances where you managed travel well despite less sleep, proving flexibility in outcomes.

title: On the run
content:
Just  got home from leaving pretty early to attend a funeral this morning.  I was really tired and sleepy.  I had only about 3 hours sleep last night.  After the funeral I ran a few errands including getting my hair did.  

Home now have about an hour to shower eat and get back on the road again to pick up the others from work and school.  Was hoping to be home much earlier to get some rest.

recommendations.recommendation: Imagining the worst-case scenario or exaggerating the potential negative outcomes of being tired and busy. - Practice cognitive restructuring by identifying these thoughts and challenging them with more balanced perspectives. Ask yourself: 'What is the worst that can happen? How would I cope if that happened? What is more likely to happen?'

Viewing the situation in black-and-white terms, such as feeling like the day must be perfect or a failure with no middle ground. - Use a thought record to identify and write down these thoughts. Challenge them by considering the gray areas and acknowledging any small successes or partial achievements throughout the day.

Taking on too many activities or responsibilities without leaving room for rest, leading to overwhelm. - Practice assertiveness training by prioritizing tasks and setting boundaries. Use the 'ABC model' to analyze the situation: identify the Activating event, your Beliefs about it, and the Consequences. Consider delegating tasks or rescheduling to allow time for rest.

content:
came across this story online.
make syou wonder about how the things you do aligns with other
Years ago I found a hefty bag of money - paper money, in the clothes section of a store. I immediately decided, without second thought to hand it in. I came downstairs and saw a few persons working in the stock-room. I handed the money to a guy and told him in the presence of other persons that I just found it upstairs in the clothes section on top of the clothes rack. The guy took the money and I left the store after paying for my purchase. Weeks later, I remembered the incident while speaking to my sister-in-law. Curious, she asked me the name of the store and a description of the person I gave the money to. Unknown to me she did some inquiries and reported back to me. She told me that she knew the guy I gave the money to, and that since then, he started to wear the best of clothes, a change from his former attire, and even later quitted the job.
I reckon it was now her concern; not mine. My conscience was clear.

title: Feeling Left Behind
content: Lately I’ve been seeing all my friends moving forward in life — new jobs, relationships, big milestones. Meanwhile, I feel like I’m stuck in the same place. I know I’m trying, but it never feels like enough. I keep thinking maybe I’ve missed my chance or that something’s wrong with me. It’s hard not to compare, and when I do, I just feel more anxious and unmotivated.

recommendations.recommendation: Thinking that not achieving milestones at the same pace as others means something is fundamentally wrong or that you've missed your chance. - Practice 'Cognitive Restructuring': Identify these catastrophic thoughts, challenge their validity by asking for evidence, and reframe them into more balanced thoughts.

Constantly comparing yourself to others, which leads to feeling inadequate or left behind. - Use 'Gratitude Journaling': Each day, write down three things you are grateful for or personal achievements you are proud of, to shift focus from others to your own journey.

Believing that efforts are only valuable if they lead to monumental success, dismissing smaller progress. - Engage in 'Breaking Down Tasks': Break goals into smaller, manageable steps, and celebrate each completed step to recognize progress and reduce feelings of being stuck.

title: uncertainty
content: Lately I’ve been seeing all my friends moving forward in life — new jobs, relationships, big milestones. Meanwhile, I feel like I’m stuck in the same place. I know I’m trying, but it never feels like enough. I keep thinking maybe I’ve missed my chance or that something’s wrong with me. It’s hard not to compare, and when I do, I just feel more anxious and unmotivated.
gpt_response:
I want to start by saying how brave you are for sharing what’s on your mind. It’s completely understandable to feel anxious when it seems like everyone around you is moving forward while you're standing still. That feeling of being stuck can be so isolating, but you're not alone in this.

It sounds like you’re really feeling the pressure to keep up with the pace of life around you, and it’s weighing heavily on your sense of self-worth. Comparing yourself to others is something many of us do, and it can be tough when it leads to anxiety and self-doubt.

Here are a couple of thought patterns that might be popping up:

Comparison Trap: This is when we measure our own worth against others' achievements. It’s easy to forget that we all have unique paths and timelines.

All-or-Nothing Thinking: This is about seeing things in black-and-white, like feeling you’re either moving forward or completely stuck. Life often has a lot more gray areas.

To help with these, here are a few things you might try:

Thought Reframing: When you catch yourself in the comparison trap, remind yourself of your own unique strengths and the progress you’ve made, however small it might seem.

Gratitude Practice: Each day, jot down a couple of things you’re grateful for in your life right now. It can help shift focus from what’s missing to what’s present.

Mindful Moments: Spend a few minutes each day just being present. Whether it’s through meditation or simply sitting quietly, it can help ground you and reduce feelings of anxiety.

And here’s a little reflection for today:
"What is one small step I can take towards my goals that feels manageable right now?"

You’re doing important work by tuning into these feelings, and every step you take is valuable. Remember, progress doesn’t always look like a big leap forward. Sometimes it’s just about taking one small, steady step at a time.

- Mind Reading
- All-or-Nothing Thinking


Warmly,
Coach Mira

All-or-Nothing Thinking: This pattern makes us see situations in extremes, like feeling either helpful or selfish. But remember, life is full of in-betweens, and setting boundaries doesn't make you any less supportive.

Gratitude Practice: At the end of the day, jot down a couple of things you're grateful for about your own work and contributions. This can help shift focus from what's overwhelming to what's fulfilling.

This can occur when you think helping others means neglecting your own needs. Remember, you can be supportive and still prioritize your tasks. - Reflect on how you can support others while still taking care of your own responsibilities.

title: Avoiding the Event
content: I was invited to a social event this weekend, but I’ve been thinking of canceling. I keep imagining myself saying something awkward or not knowing what to say. I feel like I’ll just come off as weird or boring. I’ve avoided a few gatherings like this lately because it just feels safer to stay home. But at the same time, I feel bad for always backing out. It’s like I’m stuck between wanting to connect and being afraid I’ll mess it up
gpt_response:
First off, thank you for sharing your thoughts with me. It takes courage to open up about these feelings, and it's completely okay to feel this way. You're not alone in this, and it's great that you're reflecting on it. 

It sounds like there's a lot of pressure between wanting to connect with others and the fear of how you might come across. That push and pull can be really draining, and it makes sense that you'd feel stuck right now. 

Let's look at a couple of thought patterns that might be popping up:

All-or-Nothing Thinking: This is when things feel like they're either all good or all bad. For example, thinking you have to either go to the event and be perfect or stay home to avoid any awkwardness. It's helpful to remember that there's a whole gray area in between those extremes. 
Mind Reading: You're predicting how you'll be perceived, like being seen as weird or boring, without real evidence. It's anxiety's way of filling in the blanks with fears, not facts. 

Here are a few things you might try:

Thought Reframing: When you catch yourself thinking "I'll mess it up," try to reframe it to something like "I might have awkward moments, but that's okay. Everyone does." 
Behavioral Experiment: Consider going to the event for just a short period, like 30 minutes. It's a way to dip your toes in without feeling overwhelmed by the whole night.
Gratitude Practice: After the event, jot down a few things that went well or that you appreciated. It could be as simple as a nice conversation or the fact that you showed up.

And a small reflection for today:
"What’s one thing I enjoy about connecting with others that I want to experience this weekend?"

You're doing important work by being aware of these thoughts and patterns. Remember, every step you take is progress, no matter how small.

We're starting to notice a few thought patterns in your journals. Here's what we're seeing:
- All-or-Nothing Thinking
- Mind Reading


Warmly,
Coach Mira

cbt_patterns.description: Seeing situations in black-or-white terms, without recognizing the gray areas in between.
cbt_patterns.recommendation: Thought Reframing: Challenge the extremes by considering the middle ground.

cbt_patterns.description: Predicting what others think of you without actual evidence.
cbt_patterns.recommendation: Behavioral Experiment: Attend the event for a short time to gather real feedback.

title: yes all the time
content: I told myself I wouldn’t take on anything extra this week, but when a colleague asked for help with their project, I said yes anyway. Now I’m feeling overwhelmed, behind on my own work, and frustrated with myself for not setting a boundary. I didn’t want to seem selfish or unreliable, but now I just feel drained. Why do I keep doing this to myself?
gpt_response:
I want to start by saying that it's really brave of you to share how you're feeling. It's so easy to take on too much because of the fear of being perceived as selfish or unreliable, and you're not alone in feeling overwhelmed when this happens.

You're experiencing that familiar tug-of-war between wanting to help others and needing to protect your own time and energy. It's tough to manage those boundaries, especially when anxiety whispers that saying no might make you seem uncooperative.

Let's look at a couple of thought patterns that might be at play here:

All-or-Nothing Thinking: This is when you see things in black and white, like believing that saying no makes you a bad colleague. But remember, setting boundaries doesn’t mean you’re unkind or unreliable.
Mind Reading: You're assuming your colleague might think less of you if you set a boundary. But have they actually expressed that, or is it anxiety filling in the gaps?

Here are a few strategies you could try:

Thought Reframing: Try to shift from "I have to help or they'll think I'm selfish" to "I can still be supportive without overextending myself."
Boundary Setting: Practice saying no gently. You might say, "I'm sorry, I can't take this on right now, but maybe I can help in a smaller way."
Gratitude Practice: At the end of each day, jot down one thing you accomplished or a moment you felt proud of setting a boundary, no matter how small.

And for today's reflection, consider this question:
"What small boundary could I set today that would help me feel more balanced?"

You're making progress just by being aware of these patterns. It's a journey, and you're taking important steps. Remember, even small changes count.

We're starting to notice a few thought patterns in your journals. Here's what we're seeing:
- All-or-Nothing Thinking
- Mind Reading


Warmly,
Coach Mira

cbt_patterns.description: This is when you see things in extremes, like believing you're either completely reliable or entirely selfish.
cbt_patterns.recommendation: Thought Reframing: Shift your perspective to find a more balanced view that acknowledges your ability to be supportive without overextending.

cbt_patterns.description: You're assuming others are judging you negatively without any clear evidence.
cbt_patterns.recommendation: Boundary Setting: Practice saying no in a kind way, to reinforce that setting limits doesn’t mean you’re being unhelpful.

title: Thoughts
content: I am in a relationship with someone who seems to care little about how i feel
gpt_response:
First, I want to acknowledge how brave it is for you to share your feelings. It’s not easy to admit when things feel off with someone we care about, and your openness here is a big step.

From what you’ve written, it seems like you’re feeling undervalued in your relationship. That can be really tough, especially when you’re hoping for your feelings to be acknowledged and met with genuine care.

There might be a couple of thought patterns at play here:

Mind Reading: You might be assuming your partner doesn’t care because you’re interpreting their actions this way. But unless they’ve explicitly told you this, it might be your anxiety filling in the gaps.

All-or-Nothing Thinking: It’s easy to slip into thinking that they either care completely or not at all, when in reality, feelings and actions often exist in a gray area.

Here are some gentle CBT strategies you might find helpful:

Thought Reframing: Try to catch yourself when you’re thinking "They don’t care at all" and reframe it to "There are moments when I feel unheard, but it doesn’t mean they never care."

Boundary Setting: Consider what you need to feel valued and how you could communicate this to your partner. Practicing assertive communication might help in expressing your needs more clearly.

Gratitude Practice: Reflect on any small moments where you did feel cared for. This isn’t to ignore your feelings but to create a balanced view of your relationship.

For today’s reflection:
"What would feeling cared for look like in your relationship? How might you express this to your partner?"

Remember, recognizing these feelings is a vital part of understanding and strengthening your relationship. You're doing important work by addressing this.

Warmly,
Coach Mira

title: Hello Today, Life Sucks
content:
I am a social worker and every blessed I do nothing but listen to a bunch of ungrateful people complain that life is hard but they don't want to do anything to move their lives forward. What am I doing wrong? Why can't I help them? Why can't get them to understand that life development is a journey that we take together? 

When I look back on my client list, I just shake my head and groan. I mean, I would love to cry but I have no more tears less. Perhaps I need to change my jobs 'cause I really can't take living and working at Ingrate Central anymore. But what can I do? What should I do? I don't have the passion for my work that I used to.

When I first became a social worker it was because I wanted to help people. Now it seems that I am just wasting time because no one wants a hand-up just a handout. What should I do? What do I do now? I am soooooooooooooo tired of everything
gpt_response:
I want to acknowledge the courage it takes to share your feelings, especially when you're feeling so overwhelmed. It's clear that you're passionate about your work and care deeply for those you help, and it's understandable to feel burnt out when it seems like your efforts aren't appreciated. 

You're grappling with the weight of wanting to help your clients and feeling frustrated when progress isn't visible. This can be incredibly draining, especially when your work is entwined with your sense of purpose.

Here are a few thought patterns that may be surfacing:

All-or-Nothing Thinking: It seems like you're seeing your work as either a success or a failure, with no middle ground. This can amplify feelings of frustration.
Emotional Reasoning: Feeling overwhelmed might make it seem like you're not making a difference, but feelings aren't always the full story.

Here are a few gentle CBT strategies you could try:

Thought Reframing: Try recognizing small successes in your work, even if they seem minor. Reflecting on these can shift your perspective and renew your sense of purpose.
Gratitude Practice: Each day, write down one thing you appreciate about your work or a small win. This can help balance the focus from what's draining to what's fulfilling.
Boundary Setting: Consider setting clear boundaries to protect your energy, ensuring you have time for self-care and reflection outside work.

And a little reflection for today:
"What originally inspired me to become a social worker, and how can I reconnect with that motivation in small ways?"

Remember, you're making a difference by simply being present and trying. It’s okay to take care of yourself too, and even small steps can lead to meaningful change.

Warmly,
Coach Mira

cbt_patterns.description: Viewing situations in black-or-white terms without recognizing the spectrum of possibilities in between.
cbt_patterns.recommendation: Thought Reframing: Challenge this pattern by identifying and acknowledging the gray areas and small successes in your work.

cbt_patterns.description: Believing that because you feel a certain way, it must be true.
cbt_patterns.recommendation: Gratitude Practice: Focus on positive aspects or wins, however small, to counterbalance negative feelings.

It sounds like you're grappling with feelings of frustration and exhaustion, feeling like you're giving so much of yourself but not seeing the progress you hope for. That can be incredibly disheartening, especially when you're driven by a desire to make a difference.

It sounds like you're juggling a lot right now, and it's understandable to feel overwhelmed with so many demands on your time. It's important to recognize and honor all that you're managing. Sometimes, when everything feels urgent, it can be difficult to see the bigger picture and prioritize what's truly important.

Take a moment. What's one expectation you've been holding that feels heavy — and might not be fully yours to carry?

* All-or-Nothing Thinking: You may be viewing your tasks as all equally urgent, which can make everything feel overwhelming and critical.
* Catastrophizing: There's a tendency to feel like there's never enough time, which can amplify anxiety about getting everything done.


CBT-Based Strategies:
1. Prioritization Exercise Create a list of your tasks and categorize them into 'urgent,' 'important,' and 'can wait.' This helps clarify what needs immediate attention. Spend 10 minutes listing your tasks and categorizing them today.
2. Time Blocking Allocate specific time slots for different activities to ensure you're dedicating focused time to each area without overwhelming yourself. Choose one day this week to try time blocking, even for just a couple of hours.


Warmly,
Coach Mira
